children.value: In this notebook we will cover:
How to parallelize the creation of virtual datasets using the
will be helpful, but is not required. This notebook is not intended as a tutorial for using
, but will show how to use
to greatly speedup the the generation of virtual datasets.
library for parallel computing. It plays well with
, but can be used in many ways across the
ecosystem. This notebook is not intended to be a guide for how to use
, but just an example of how to use
, we were looking at daily downscaled climate data over South-Eastern Alaska. We created a virtual dataset for each input file using list comprehension in Python.
in parallel, which allows us to create multiple virtual datasets at the same time.
Further on in this notebook, we will show how using
can greatly speed-up the process of creating a virtual datasets.
In the code below, we are importing
. This is the start of our parallel
data processing. We are passing the argument
client on some of the resource limitations.
Note: Depending on if you are running on a small machine such as a laptop or a larger compute hub, these resources could be tuned to improve performance.

import logging

from distributed import Client

client = Client(n_workers=8, silence_logs=logging.ERROR)
client

Building off of our Previous Work

children.label: Building off of our Previous Work

children.value: In the next section, we will re-use some of the code from the
notebook. However, we will modify it slightly to make it compatible with
The following two cells should look the same as before.  As a reminder we are importing the required libraries, using
to create a list of our input files and setting up some kwargs for

import dask
import fsspec
from virtualizarr import open_virtual_dataset

# Initiate fsspec filesystems for reading and writing
fs_read = fsspec.filesystem("s3", anon=True, skip_instance_cache=True)

# Retrieve list of available days in archive for the year 2060.
files_paths = fs_read.glob("s3://wrf-se-ak-ar5/ccsm/rcp85/daily/2060/*")

# Here we prepend the prefix 's3://', which points to AWS.
files_paths = sorted(["s3://" + f for f in files_paths])
To speed up our example, lets take a subset of the year of data.

# If the subset_flag == True (default), the list of input files will
# be subset to speed up the processing
subset_flag = True
if subset_flag:
    files_paths = files_paths[0:4]
Here is the section of code that will change. Instead of iterating through each input file and using
to create the virtual datasets, we are iterating through our input file list and creating
. It is not super important to understand this, but a
is lazy, meaning it is not computed eagerly. Once we have iterated through all our input files, we end up with a list of
When we are ready, we can call
on this list of delayed objects to create virtual datasets in parallel.

storage_options = dict(anon=True, default_fill_cache=False, default_cache_type="none")
# Generate Dask Delayed objects
tasks = [
    dask.delayed(generate_virtual_dataset)(file, storage_options)
    for file in files_paths
]
it can be hard to understand what is happening and how far along the process is at any time. Fortunately,
has a built in dashboard to help visualize your progress.
earlier on, it should have returned some information including an address to the
By navigating to this address, you should a
dashboard that looks something like this.
, the dashboard should populate with a bunch of tasks. In the dashboard you can monitor your progress, see how resources are being used as well as well as countless other functionality.
If you are running this example notebook on
dashboard should look slightly different. Since

is running the notebook on another computer, navigating to localhost will give you an error.
The
graph should look something more like this:

children.value:
To demonstrate how Dask can speed-up your virtual dataset generation, the next section will show the timing of generating reference files with and without Dask.
For reference, the timing was run on a large AWS Jupyter-Hub (managed by the fine folks at
) with ~16 CPU and ~64 GB RAM. It is also important to note that the data is also hosted on AWS.
version on the year of data took only ~36 seconds. In comparison, creating the
virtual datasets one-by-one took about 7 minutes and 22 seconds.
Just by changing a few lines of code and using
, we got our code to run
. One other detail to note is that there is usually a bit of a delay as
builds its task graph before any of the tasks are started. All that to say, you may see even better performance when using
Note: These timings may vary for you. There are many factors that may affect performance, such as:
Geographical location of your compute and the source data
Compute resources, IO limits and # of workers given to
Location of where to write reference files to (cloud vs local)
This is meant to be an example of how
In this notebook we demonstrated how
can be used to parallelize the creation of virtual datasets. In the following
section, we will walk though examples of using
Additionally, if you wish to explore more of
integration, you can try checking out
method, which combines many of the
setup steps into a single convenient function.
